intro: Chamaesyce makinoi, commonly known as Makino's sandmat, is a low-growing perennial plant native to Japan. It belongs to the family Portulacaceae and is characterized by its fleshy, succulent leaves that are often covered in a fine layer of white, powdery wax. The plant produces small, inconspicuous yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in open, sun-exposed areas. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in specialty gardens.
